<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 0625/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 840]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2

4
Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 867, 727, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 782, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions. Use the ray-trace sheet supplied, referring to Fig. 2.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 149, 771, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 616, 532, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 647, 144, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 647, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long near the top of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line MR. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal NL. Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 708, 180, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 708, 628, 726]]<|/det|>
Draw a line CD 8.0 cm below MR and parallel to MR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 740, 180, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 740, 527, 758]]<|/det|>
Label the point X where CD crosses NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 771, 180, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 771, 620, 789]]<|/det|>
Draw a line EF 8.0 cm below CD and parallel to CD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 803, 180, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 803, 524, 821]]<|/det|>
Label the point Y where EF crosses NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 816, 920, 834]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Draw a line 7.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(\theta_{1} = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 150, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 144, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 670, 199]]<|/det|>
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 2.1. Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\). Label the position of \(\mathsf{P}_3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) so that pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\), all appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Label the position of \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 305, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 146, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 336, 180, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 336, 594, 355]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(a\) from \(\mathbf{X}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 413, 181, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 413, 594, 432]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(b\) from \(\mathbf{Y}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 458, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 490, 180, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 301, 514]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\frac{a}{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 533, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{a}{b} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 144, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 583, 803, 600]]<|/det|>
Repeat the steps in parts **(b)** and **(c)** using an angle of incidence \(\theta_2 = 10^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 594, 631]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(c\) from \(\mathbf{X}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 660, 918, 678]]<|/det|>
<form>c = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 594, 710]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(d\) from \(\mathbf{Y}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 737, 918, 755]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 768, 301, 787]]<|/det|>
<form>Calculate \(\frac{c}{d}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 826, 920, 853]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{c}{d} =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 846, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 143, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the values of \(\frac{a}{b}\) and \(\frac{c}{d}\) can be considered to be equal in this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 156, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 189, 146, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 188, 920, 222]]<|/det|>
A student carries out this experiment with care. Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 267, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 690, 318]]<|/det|>
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 4 and 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 329, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 527, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 129, 833, 349]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 364, 532, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 144, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 395, 185, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 339, 415]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 427, 485, 446]]<|/det|>
Measure the current \(I\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 469, 920, 489]]<|/det|>
<form>I = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 501, 181, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 501, 460, 520]]<|/det|>
Place the sliding contact S at C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 532, 719, 552]]<|/det|>
Measure the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) across the resistor R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 574, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>R</sub> = ......................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 607, 298, 626]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 638, 178, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 631, 761, 656]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the resistor using the equation \(R = \frac{V_{\mathrm{R}}}{I}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 680, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 712, 148, 731]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 712, 920, 749]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter from terminal B. Connect the voltmeter to terminal C. Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 759, 685, 778]]<|/det|>
· Place the sliding contact S at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 790, 712, 810]]<|/det|>
· Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the reading on the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 821, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
· Repeat the procedure using \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}, 60.0 \text{cm}, 80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(100.0 \text{cm}\). Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 42, 507, 59]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 97, 742, 263]]<|/det|>
\(l/\mathrm {cm}\)\(V/V\)
20.0
40.0
60.0
80.0
100.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 250, 920, 267]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 280, 146, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 280, 848, 299]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(V/V\) (y-axis) against \(l/\mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 310, 798, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 743, 920, 761]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 146, 791]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 772, 920, 822]]<|/det|> Use your value of \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) from **(a)(ii)** to find the length \(l_{\mathrm{R}}\) of resistance wire that has the same resistance as resistor R. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 850, 920, 870]]<|/det|>
\(l_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .................................................... $cm$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 866, 920, 885]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 897, 920, 916]]<|/det|> [Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 596, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates springs made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 826, 120]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the extension of springs made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 524, 151]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 420, 182]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 197, 346, 212]]<|/det|>
boss, clamp and stand

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 245, 228]]<|/det|>
metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 445, 243]]<|/det|>
springs made from different metals

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 420, 259]]<|/det|>
selection of loads with hangers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 907, 290]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 324, 320]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 511, 352]]<|/det|>
• write a list of suitable metals for the springs

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 366, 517, 382]]<|/det|>
• draw a diagram of the set up you would use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 549, 414]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how to carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 487, 444]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 672, 523]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
